awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Interactive Software for Hyperspectral Image Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to simplify the workflow, reduce analysis time, and enable deep searching capabilities across hyperspectral datasets using a new computational platform. Hyperspectral imaging, or chemical imaging,  is the combination of spectroscopy and digital imaging.  The proposed system incorporates advanced imaging and machine learning algorithms to streamline data processing and enable users to focus on the application itself, rather than spending time and money on developing image processing algorithms. Hyperspectral imaging is broadly used to diagnose diseases and measure a patient's response to therapy, to enhance product quality by enabling optical sorters to identify and remove defective products, and to identify minerals from drill cores and remote sensing.  A potential early application for the software platform will be in agriculture to identify early stress in crops, assess soil health, quantify water resources, and predict harvest yields.

This I-Corps project further develops a software platform for deep mining of data derived from hyperspectral imaging. The system performs several essential operations in the spectral imaging domain and enables advanced image analysis for users across a range of technical proficiencies. The strength of the proposed software lies in its intuitive design that enables the user to perform high level data analysis from image processing to machine learning via a visual, interactive interface. Built around a collection of current and proprietary spectral imaging algorithms, the software facilitates the search of hidden information inside large datasets, providing broad improvements in data analysis. The package can be operated without prior programming skills and allows most currently used data formats to be processed in real time. The interactivity, object identification, and machine learning algorithms enable high efficiency during analysis of hyperspectral images.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The main aim of the I-CORPS/PFI-TT project is to develop and expand a customer base for hyperspectral imaging (HSI) in agriculture-related fields. HSI is a cutting-edge technology that provides comprehensive details about objects with greater precision than traditional color cameras. To address the current technology gap in precision agriculture and related fields, we have developed IDCube as an advanced computational platform that utilizes state-of-the-art algorithms for HSI, which offer greater efficiency and throughput than current products on the market. IDCube simplifies the process of image analysis, allowing users to mine datasets from remote platforms like drones, planes, and satellites, and provides an easy-to-use web interface that facilitates near-real time crop analysis, early detection of stress, and risk assessment. This software has been developed with NSF support and is highly versatile, offering a range of essential operations in spectral imaging for advanced image analysis across technical proficiencies. The software allows users to perform high-level data analysis through a visual, interactive interface, making it accessible to almost anyone, regardless of programming skills. I-CORPS helped the team to focus on the agricultural aspect of the technology with the goal of establishing IDCube as a valuable and growing market niche in the precision agriculture and related fields. The intellectual merits of this project lie in the development of a highly versatile software that simplifies the process of spectral imaging analysis, enabling users to uncover hidden information and perform advanced image analysis with ease.

Hyperspectral imaging has a significant societal impact and is quickly growing. It has already led to the development of new medical diagnostic tools, methods for ensuring food quality, discovery of minerals, and advancements in national defense projects. Our IDCube hyperspectral software has been designed with a simple and user-friendly interface to educate farmers on this new technology, identify potential new markets in agriculture, and forecast environmental stress. Our ultimate goal is to make hyperspectral imaging accessible to a wide range of customers, from large agriculture businesses and research institutions to small farms, in order to enhance their commercial sustainability.

Throughout this funding period, our team conducted interviews with over 100 potential customers to gain insight into their needs. Based on their feedback, the team has integrated improved algorithms into our software, with a focus on vegetation identification and other important indices. The team currently collaborating with several interviewees to better understand their specific requirements. The results of our research were presented at several international conferences, including SPIE 2023. In addition, the PI has been invited by several industry partners to deliver talks on hyperspectral imaging.

 


Last Modified: 04/17/2023
Modified by: Mikhail Y Berezin

  • Interactive Interface IDCube for hyperspectral image analysis

    Mikhail Y Berezin
    IDCube Interface
